newsitem.title: USA: Space station cost overruns now $219 mln- analysis.
newsitem.headline: Space station cost overruns now $219 mln- analysis.

text.p: Cost overruns for the troubled international space station have reached $219 million, triple what they were in April 1996, according to a U.S. government analysis made available on Thursday.

The analysis by the General Accounting Office also said the cost needed to get the much-postponed space station back on schedule has increased in the same period of time by nearly 50 percent, to $129 million.

The escalating cost and slipping schedule were due to money problems in Russia, a key partner in construction of the station, as well as deteriorating performance by the station's prime U.S. contractor, Boeing, the analysis said.

The analysis was requested by Sen. Dale Bumpers, an Arkansas Democrat who said the station should be scrapped and the money used to fund the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation and to cut the federal deficit.
"Bringing Russia into the program would have been laudable if Russia's economy hadn't been in shambles and if Russia hadn't been flat broke," Bumpers said in a statement.
"NASA's decision in 1993 to make Russia a partner was a cynical ploy to gin up political support for a project that was heading toward a richly deserved cancellation," Bumpers said.
The United States has spent $18 billion so far on the international space station, which has undergone numerous reschedulings and design changes since first being envisioned in the early 1980s.
